ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The as-prepared Cu/NC@SBA-15 composites are highly active for the hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone, giving a maximum yield as high as 92 % at 140 ºC in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor.

The hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is a common reaction that is critical to biomass transformation. However, it is a great challenge to employ non-noble metal catalysts in realizing highly effective conversion from LA to GVL. Herein, we report an efficient strategy for anchoring highly active copper nanocluster catalysts on the defect sites of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and dispersing in mesoporous silica (SBA-15). The combination of g-C3N4 and SBA-15 stabilized the copper clusters, leading to a high GVL yield of 92 % and excellent stability in 100 h. This result is comparable to that of the Ru/AC catalyst but much more economically favorable. Density functional theory calculations revealed that the reaction barrier of the new catalyst was reduced from 1.93 to 1.12 eV compared with those of unconfined copper particles. This research provides a simple anchoring strategy for constructing highly active and inexpensive copper nanocluster catalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: Thermal catalytic hydrogenation is a very important reaction of broad and current interest, which has been employed to produce a wide variety of compounds in recent decades. Despite this, the harsh reaction conditions (high temperature and high pressure) also bring tremendous energy consumption and safety concerns. Some studies are increasingly showing that using high activity catalysts can make the reaction take place under more mild conditions [1,2]. The development of highly active and inexpensive hydrogenation catalysts not only reduces cost, but also saves energy, reduces carbon emissions, and protects our safety and environment [3].

The production of sustainable chemicals and fuels from renewable resources has gathered much attention with the excessive depletion of worldwide fossil energy reserves in recent years [4,5]. Biomass is considered to be a potential alternative to fossil resources thanks to its low cost, rich natural reserves, and easy availability [6]. The efficient utilization of renewable biomass is beneficial for alleviating strained fossil resources as well as realizing the goal of carbon neutral and low-carbon economies. Over the past few decades, great efforts have been put into the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into valuable chemicals such as hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), lactic acid, levulinic acid (LA), and γ-valerolactone (GVL) [7–9]. Among these platform molecules, GVL has played a pivotal role in bio-refinery systems because it can be utilized as a green solvent, a food additive, an approved fuel additive, and an important intermediate in the synthesis of many fine chemicals including 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (MTHF), 1,4-pentanediol (PDO), and adipic acid [10,11]. Therefore, large-scale production of GVL is critical to improving the competitiveness of biomass resources instead of fossil resources.

To date, some publications have revealed that GVL can be obtained through the hydrogenation and cyclization of LA or its esters in the presence of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [12–17]. García et al. have found that palladium homogeneous catalysts were efficient in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [5]. Although possessing highly active and selective catalytic centers for the transformation of LA to GVL, homogeneous catalysts suffer from the drawbacks of difficult catalyst separation and recycling procedures. Hence, heterogeneous catalysts should be more practical for GVL production on a massive scale. Especially, supported metal catalysts have attracted a great deal of interest. Among various supported metal catalysts, Ru loaded on activated carbon (Ru/AC) is regarded as the most effective catalyst for selective catalytic hydrogenation of LA to GVL, and was therefore extensively investigated [18–22]. Upare et al. studied the hydrogenation activity of 5 wt.% Ru/AC catalyst in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor and found it gave a GVL yield of nearly 100 % at 265 °C [20]. However, Ru-based catalysts tend to aggregate during the reaction process and show a tendency of slow deactivation due to acid-assisted metal leaching and coke formation [14,21]. Moreover, the widespread practical application of Ru-based catalysts is greatly restricted because of economic considerations.

Recent studies have revealed that non-noble metal catalysts, such as supported Ni and Cu catalysts, can also catalyze the hydrogenation of LA to GVL but suffer from harsh reaction conditions including high temperature or pressure [16,23–28]. For instance, Hutchings et al. synthesized a Cu-ZrO2 catalyst, which afforded a GVL yield of around 70 % at 200 °C and 2.7 MPa [29]. Obregón et al. found that Cu/Al2O3 obtained a 66 % GVL yield at 250 °C and 6.5 MPa [30]. Furthermore, the hydrogenation over these Cu-based catalysts were mostly performed in tank reactors, where it is difficult to yield GVL continuously.

To realize a highly efficient conversion of LA to GVL based on non-noble metal catalysts at mild conditions, new catalyst structures need to be designed. Yao et al. assembled highly dispersed copper species into a silica network, achieving an excellent hydrogenation activity of dimethyl oxalate to ethylene glycol [31]. For a supported metal catalyst, the size of the metal particles significantly influences the catalytic activity as metal nanoparticles with ultra-small size can expose abundant active edges and corner atoms [32]. Many published papers have indicated that modifying supports with N-doped carbon materials was conducive to dispersal of metal nanoparticles and in restriction of the growth of metal nanoparticles [33,34]. Lee et al. utilized the nanoconfinement effect of N-doped carbon layers to develop ultrafine Pt nanoparticles as the electrocatalyst for the oxygen reduction reaction [35]. To the best of our knowledge, ultrafine Cu species nanoconfined by g-C3N4 within porous silica has not been reported in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, thus this structure is worthy of being studied.

In this work, we reported an efficient strategy for anchoring highly active copper nanocluster catalysts on the defect sites of graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and dispersing in mesoporous silica (SBA-15). This composite catalyst, denoted as Cu/NC@SBA-15, was simply fabricated by pyrolyzing a mixture of Cu(NO3)2 and urea impregnated in SBA-15, and subsequently reduced in hydrogen. The g-C3N4 offered anchoring sites to prevent the agglomeration of Cu clusters during the synthesis and reaction process. The as-obtained catalysts were employed in the reaction of LA hydrogenation to GVL in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. The combination of several characterization techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) revealed that ultrafine Cu clusters were uniformly dispersed within SBA-15, which was attributed to the strong coordination between the N species and Cu ions. Moreover, DFT calculations were used to reveal the reason for higher activity of Cu/NC@SBA-15. This research provides a simple anchoring strategy for constructing highly active and inexpensive copper nanocluster catalysts.

Triblock copolymer Pluronic P123 (EO20PO70EO20, molecular weight 5800), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 99 %), urea (CO(NH2)2, 99 %), and levulinic acid (CH3COCH2CH2COOH, 99 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. Methanol (CH3OH, 99 %), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 38 %), and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %) were obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. The commercial 5 wt.% Ru/AC catalyst was supplied by Meryer Chemical Technology Co. Ltd. The chemicals utilized in this study were all analytical reagents and used without further purification.

Mesoporous SiO2 (SBA-15) was synthesized using the classic procedure found in Zhao et al. [36]. Specifically, a mixture of 8 g of Pluronic P123 and 300 mL of 1.6 mol L−1 HCl solution was continuously stirred at 38 °C until the templating agent was completely dissolved. Then, 17 g of TEOS was slowly added under vigorous stirring and the mixed solution was kept stirring at this temperature for another 24 h. Thereafter, the obtained milky mixture was transferred to a 500 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and subsequently given hydrothermal treatment in an oven at 100 °C for 24 h. After filtering, washing, and drying, the white product was calcined at 600 °C for 2 h in air to obtain the final SBA-15.

The Cu/NC@SBA-15 catalyst was prepared by the conventional incipient-wetness impregnation method. In a typical synthetic process, 3.5 g of urea and 3.3 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were firstly dissolved in deionized water. Next, 3.5 g of the calcined SBA-15 support was impregnated with the above mixed solution of Cu(NO3)2 and urea. The wet sample was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 6 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 2 h with a heating ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 in nitrogen. Subsequently, the obtained CuO/NC@SBA-15 composite material was reduced at 500 °C for 1 h under a constant hydrogen flow of 60 mL min−1 to achieve the final Cu/NC@SBA-15 catalyst. The samples prepared with different mass ratios of urea to SBA-15 were labeled as Cu/NC@SBA-15-X (X = 0.3, 0.7, 1.0, and 1.4). For all catalysts, the loading amount of metal Cu was fixed to be 20 wt.%. As a comparison, Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/C@SBA-15 catalysts were also synthesized (See Supporting Information).

Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku SmartLab equipment using Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) radiation with the accelerating voltage and the current applied of 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. N2 physisorption characters were investigated using a DKSH Belsorp-Max apparatus by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were calculated by applying the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Prior to performing N2 sorption measurements, all samples were pretreated at 150 °C for at least 10 h. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on a FEI Talos F200X G2, AEMC field emission microscope operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were implemented on an ESCALab250Xi electron spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1484.6 eV) as X-ray source and all binding energies were corrected by a C 1s at 284.6 eV. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) measurements were conducted on a Rigaku Super Mini 200 instrument for Cu content analysis. Elemental analysis (EA) was performed using a Vario EL cube elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was collected at a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS5 infrared spectrometer. Raman spectra were obtained using a Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution confocal Raman microscope with a 785 nm excitation laser. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experimentations were performed by utilizing a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 gas-adsorption instrument to study the reduction properties of metal oxides on the surface of various catalysts. Typically, 100 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz reactor and pretreated at 200 °C for 2 h under N2 atmosphere. After that, the cooled sample was heated up to 600 °C in a gas flow of 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixture (30 mL min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The hydrogen consumption was monitored by a thermal conductive detector (TCD).

LA hydrogenation reactions were performed on a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Prior to the test, all catalysts were pelleted, crushed, and sieved with 20–40 mesh. In a typical run, a certain amount of catalyst diluted with quartz sand was placed in the center of the reactor and exterior gaseous H2 was applied as the H2 source. The liquid feed (10 wt.% LA dissolved in methanol solvent) was introduced into the reactor by a liquid metering pump (Beijing Oushisheng Experimental Apparatus Co. Ltd.). The reactions were performed at various temperature (100–220 °C), H2 pressure (0.1–3 MPa), and liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV, 2‒5 h−1) conditions with a constant volume ratio of H2 gas to liquid feed (H2/oil = 1600). A high-performance gas chromatograph (HPGC, Agilent 7890A) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP5-MS column was used to analyze the composition of the liquid product. On the basis of GC–MS (Agilent 7890A/5975C) analytic results, the major products of hydrogenation of LA are identified to be GVL, MTHF, 1,4-pentanediol (PDO), methyl levulinate (ML), and some other byproducts. Plane-wave Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were set up using the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) Python package, with the CASTEP software used as the calculator for electronic energy minimizations, force evaluations, and geometry optimizations [38–42]. The calculations were performed using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional, with Grimme’s D3 semi-empirical dispersion correction enabled throughout [43–45]. Calculations were converged with respect to plane-wave kinetic energy cut-off and Brillouin zone sampling, using 600 eV and 6 k-points per periodic dimension, respectively. All systems were geometry optimized prior to performing charge and binding energy calculations and before doing transition state search using the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method [46,47]. See supporting information for more computational details.

To study the function of g-C3N4 and N dopants, the Cu/SBA-15 without g-C3N4 and Cu/C@SBA-15 with N-free carbon were also prepared (for details, See Supporting Information). All Cu particles were formed by reduction of CuO precursors after annealing at 500 °C in H2. Fig. S2b (Supporting Information) presents the XRD patterns of Cu species prior to reduction over different catalysts, and CuO/NC@SBA-15−1.0 exhibits broader and weaker CuO peaks compared with the other two samples, indicating its smaller particle size. Determined by XRF measurements (Table 2 ), the amount of Cu loading in samples of Cu/SBA-15, Cu/C@SBA-15, and the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst are 22.7 wt.%, 21.5 wt.%, and 19.2 wt.%, respectively.

Small-angle XRD pattern (Fig. 1 a) shows that pristine SBA-15 depicts three obvious diffraction peaks at 1.3°, 2.2°, and 2.4°, which can be attributed to the (100), (110), and (200) reflections of ordered two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal mesostructure, respectively [48]. For the other three samples, the major (100) diffraction peak of 2D hexagonal structure can be distinctly observed, indicating that the load of metal Cu and modification with carbon or g-C3N4 do not significantly affect the symmetry of the mesoporous framework. The diffraction peaks in the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 sample become unapparent, however, which may be caused by a small fraction of channels being filled [49].

In the wide-angle XRD patterns (Fig. 1b), all the samples show a broad SiO2 diffraction peak over the 2θ range of 15‒30°. Clearly, the Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/C@SBA-15 present three sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ of 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1°, which are in correspondence with the (111), (200), and (220) crystal faces of metal Cu (JCPDS card No. 04-0836), respectively [16]. Nevertheless, in the sample of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0, only a very weak and broad diffraction peak centered at 2θ of 43.3° can be detected, implying that the Cu is ultrafine and highly dispersed in the channels of SBA-15. The diffraction peak at around 36.4° is assigned to the (111) crystal face of Cu2O (JCPDS card No. 65-3288) [16]. The presence of Cu2O species is attributable to the strong interaction between ultrafine copper species and g-C3N4, making it hard to be thoroughly reduced to metallic Cu. The inherited particle size and distribution from CuO precursors are ascribed to ample N sites that limit the growth of Cu species [50]. To our delight, the special property is preserved even under harsh reduction conditions. Significantly, the Cu dispersion of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 was determined to be 49.2 % by H2-N2O titration (Table 2), which was much higher than that of Cu/SBA-15 (26.5 %) and Cu/C@SBA-15 (29.7 %).

To further verify this point, TEM characterization was conducted. As illustrated in Fig. 2 a, pristine SBA-15 possesses ordered and smooth mesoporous channels with a pore diameter of around 4–5 nm. After loading Cu nanoparticles, the mesoporous structure of SBA-15 does not change (Fig. 2b‒d). Fig. 2b shows that, in the sample of Cu/SBA-15, numerous bulky Cu particles with a particle size around 16–22 nm are severely aggregated on the external surface of SBA-15. By comparison, a large number of ultrafine Cu clusters in the range of 2.2–3.7 nm are uniformly dispersed in the mesochannels of SBA-15 in Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 composite, as revealed in Fig. 2d and Fig. 3 a, b. High-resolution TEM images of the copper species over composites of Cu/SBA-15 (Fig. S3, Supporting Information) and Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 (inset of Fig. 3b and Fig. S4a‒d, Supporting Information) show a lattice fringe of 0.209 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of fcc Cu [51]. Moreover, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) images (Fig. 3c, d and Fig. S4e, f, Supporting Information) further confirm the good dispersion of tiny Cu clusters as the white dots are indisputably assigned to Cu clusters due to the Z-contrast distinction. In addition, the corresponding elemental mapping results, shown in Fig. 3e, clearly demonstrates the even distribution of Si, O, C, N, and Cu elements in the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 sample. In order to reveal the importance of N sites for the formation of tiny Cu clusters, the TEM image of Cu/C@SBA-15 composite synthesized by employing the residual templating agent P123 (N free) as carbon source was also collected. As shown in Fig. 2c, large Cu nanoparticles with the size of 13–19 nm can be distinctly observed. The XRD results, TEM, and HAADF-STEM images coupled with elemental maps confirm that one-step pyrolysis of the mixture of urea and Cu(NO3)2 impregnated in mesopores of SBA-15 can achieve tiny and evenly dispersed Cu clusters by taking advantage of the coordination of g-C3N4 and confinement effect of SBA-15.

Fig. S5 (Supporting Information) displays the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of pure SBA-15 and composites of Cu/SBA-15, Cu/C@SBA-15, and Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0. All the samples exhibit the characteristic profile of type IV isotherm accompanied with a H1-type hysteresis loop, typically behaving as mesoporous materials. A steep increase of N2 adsorption is observed within a narrow relative pressure of 0.45‒0.70, which is ascribed to the capillary condensation of N2, implying the existence of relatively uniform mesoporous channels [52]. This is in good agreement with the narrow pore diameter distribution of the samples, as depicted in the inset of Fig. S5 (Supporting Information). The textural properties of the obtained samples are summarized in Table 2. Remarkably, the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 composite exhibits a drastic decrease in specific surface area (SBET) and total pore volume (Vtotal) in comparison with composites of Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/C@SBA-15, suggesting that the mesochannels of SBA-15 are evenly covered with Cu clusters [53,54]. A similar trend is observed for all Cu/NC@SBA-15 composite catalysts prepared with various mass ratios of urea to SBA-15 (Table S1, Supporting Information). The smaller SBET and Vtotal indicate the higher utilization of mesoporous channels and a more uniform distribution of Cu species, which is in accordance with the above TEM image analysis results.

The chemical composition and state of elements in the composite catalysts were investigated using XPS characterization (Fig. 4 ). The presence of Si, O, and Cu can be clearly observed in the XPS whole spectra (Fig. S6a, Supporting Information) for all the three composites of Cu/SBA-15, Cu/C@SBA-15, and Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0. The XPS fine spectra of Cu 2p (Fig. 4a) shows two primary peaks centered at binding energies of 932.6 and 952.5 eV, corresponding to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively [55]. It should be noted that, in the Cu 2p detailed scan spectrum of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 composite, two peaks with binding energies at 934.6 and 954.8 eV accompanied with two satellite peaks at 943.4 and 962.8 eV, evidently assigned to Cu2+ species, can also be detected [56]. It is likely attributed to the formation of Cu-N coordination. The Cu LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 4b) of the composites can be deconvoluted into two major peaks located at 918.0 and 915.7 eV, indicating the coexistence of Cu° (918.0 eV) and Cu+ (915.7 eV) [57,58]. Significantly, the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst has the highest molar ratio of Cu+/(Cu° + Cu+) among the three samples, which is presumed to be induced by a strong interaction between Cu species and g-C3N4. As a result, the appearance of high-valence Cu (i.e., Cu+ and Cu2+) is possibly due to introduction of heteroatomic N. The N 1s XPS fine spectrum (Fig. 4c) of pure g-C3N4 depicts two major peaks centered at 398.6 and 399.8 eV, which are corresponding to sp2 bonded N in the tri-s-triazine (CNC) and bridging nitrogen atoms in N(C)3, respectively [59]. FT-IR spectra, XRD patterns, and Raman spectra (Fig. S7, Supporting Information) verify that the CN species embedded in the mesochannels of SBA-15 is g-C3N4 structure. The characteristic N 1s peaks in NC@SBA-15 (Fig. 4c) are slightly positive shift compared with pure g-C3N4, which might be ascribed to the intimate interaction between g-C3N4 and the channel walls of SBA-15. Interestingly, in comparison to pure NC@SBA-15 support (Fig. 4c), the binding energy of CNC bond in the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst shifts to lower energies, which also results from a strong coordination effect of N sites to Cu species resulting in the electron density of N increased [50,60,61]. The presence of pyridinic N is primarily attributed to that excessive copper species can inhibit the polymeric condensation of g-C3N4 precursor, which results in the formation of some amorphous nitrogen-doped carbon species. The C 1s XPS fine spectra of the samples (Fig. S6b, Supporting Information) can be deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 284.6, 286.3, and 288.1 eV, corresponding to the sp2 hybridized C atoms, CNHx on the edges of heptazine units, and sp2-bonded C in NCN, respectively [59]. The high intensity of sp2 hybridized C atoms (284.6 eV) in NC@SBA-15 and Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 is mainly contributed from external surface impurities.

Fig. 4d presents the H2-TPR profiles of different Cu-based composite catalysts. For both Cu/SBA-15 composite and Cu/C@SBA-15 composite, a broad reduction region at 175–380 °C is observed. The Cu/SBA-15 catalyst displays a major reduction peak at 334 °C and a shoulder peak at 285 °C. The shoulder peak at 285 °C is probably corresponding to the reduction of large CuO particles while the major peak at 334 °C is possibly attributed to the reduction of bulky aggregates of CuO. Interestingly, the major and shoulder peak positions of Cu/C@SBA-15 are inverse with respect to those of Cu/SBA-15. More significantly, however, in comparison with Cu/SBA-15 and Cu/C@SBA-15, the H2 consumption peak of the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst shifts to a much lower temperature. A relatively narrow reduction peak centered at 176 °C is distinctly discerned in the H2-TPR profile of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0. The presence of such a reduction peak suggests a relatively small size and uniform dispersion of Cu clusters in NC@SBA-15 support. Additionally, the H2-TPR experiments of Cu/NC@SBA-15 composites synthesized with different mass ratios of urea to SBA-15 were also performed (Fig. S8, Supporting Information). Evidently, the reduction peaks of CuO species for all Cu/NC@SBA-15-X samples shift to relatively low temperatures. Along with the mass ratio of urea/SBA-15 increase, the major reduction peak firstly tends towards lower temperature and then slightly increases with the lowest reduction temperature of 176 °C obtained over the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst. The H2-TPR results are well in accordance with all the above analyses.

The catalytic hydrogenation of LA to GVL was evaluated by using a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor (Fig. S9, Supporting Information). The possible reaction pathway is illustrated in Scheme 2 . Initially, the dependence of LA conversion and GVL yield on reaction temperature was studied. As shown in Fig. 5 a, a complete LA conversion and the maximum GVL yield of 92 % are achieved over the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst at a mild temperature of 140 °C. The reaction temperature is much lower than those reported in literatures but achieving an excellent GVL yield (Table S2, Supporting Information). Under identical conditions, however, Cu/SBA-15 catalyst only gives a GVL yield of 37 % and the main product is methyl levulinate (ML). With reaction temperature elevated, the yield of GVL decreases gradually over Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst due to the deep hydrogenation of GVL into MTHF and PDO. Additionally, some other side reactions occur at higher reaction temperatures. Only a slight increase of GVL yield is observed over a wide temperature range of 140−200 °C when using the Cu/SBA-15 sample. The GVL yield reaches only 80 %, even when the reaction temperature rose to 220 °C. Significantly, the LA conversion and GVL yield are sharply decreased with Cu/SBA-15 as a catalyst when the temperature is below 140 °C. In strong contrast, the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst still displays a good hydrogenation activity, giving a LA conversion of 93 % with the GVL yield of 71 % at 120 °C and a LA conversion of 65 % with the GVL yield of 52 % at 100 °C. The ultrasmall size of the Cu species over the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst can promote the accessibility to reactants and H2 dissociation, and thus could boost the hydrogenation of carbon-oxygen bonds [62]. To further investigate the intrinsic catalytic activity, turnover frequency (TOF) values of different catalysts were calculated at a low GVL yield (below 20 %). The optimal Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst gives a TOF value of 5.42 h−1 (Table S3, Supporting Information), which is 4.4 and 4.1 times higher than that of Cu/SBA-15 (1.24 h−1) and Cu/C@SBA-15 (1.33 h−1), respectively. Moreover, the apparent activation energy (Ea) value over the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst was measured to be 35.6 kJ mol–1 (Fig. 5d), which was much lower than that of Cu/SBA-15 (57.9 kJ mol−1) and Cu/C@SBA-15 (52.3 kJ mol−1). These results indicate that the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst is abundant with active sites with lower reaction energy barriers, which would facilitate LA hydrogenation to GVL.

The dependence of the mass ratio of urea to SBA-15 on the GVL yield of composite catalysts was investigated, and the result is presented in Fig. S10 (Supporting Information). Compared with Cu/SBA-15 catalyst, the GVL yield is obviously enhanced for Cu/NC@SBA-15 composites. According to the hydrogenation activities, the optimal mass ratio of urea to SBA-15 is 1.0, which leads to the ultrasmall size and high dispersion of the copper active species, with a GVL yield as high as 92 % obtained. Moreover, the hydrogenation performances of Cu/NC@SBA-15 catalysts synthesized by different methods were also studied (Fig. S11, Supporting Information). The results clearly show that the Cu/NC@SBA-15 catalyst prepared by one-step pyrolyzation of the mixture of Cu(NO3)2 and urea impregnated in mesoporous SBA-15, which leads to tiny Cu clusters coordinating with g-C3N4 uniformly distributed over the inner surface of SBA-15, is optimal for hydrogenation of LA to GVL.

In light of the above observations, a reaction temperature of 140 °C and the representative Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst were chosen for the subsequent investigation. The effect of H2 pressure on the catalytic activity was deeply studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 5b. The catalyst of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 exhibits a complete LA conversion with around 92 % GVL yield over the H2 pressure range of 3‒1 MPa. It is worth mentioning that Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 displays favorable hydrogenation activities even at relatively low H2 pressures, giving a LA conversion of 85 % with the GVL yield of 68 % at 0.3 MPa H2 and a LA conversion of 63 % with the GVL yield of 53 % at 0.1 MPa H2. However, significant decreases in both LA conversion and GVL yield are obtained for the Cu/SBA-15 catalyst as the H2 pressure drops especially at relatively low H2 pressures. The GVL yield drops to just 9 % and 5 % at 0.3 and 0.1 MPa H2, respectively. Obviously, the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst shows remarkably higher LA conversion and GVL yield in comparison with Cu/SBA-15 at low H2 pressures. As Cu clusters in the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 sample are ultrafine and highly dispersed, H2 molecules can readily access more Cu active sites, which may account for the decent hydrogenation activity at low H2 pressures. In order to rule out the effect of catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) on LA hydrogenation to GVL using methanol as solvent, the pressurized H2 gas (0.3 MPa) supply was replaced with N2. The GVL yield dramatically decreases from 68 % to 1 % (Fig. S12, Supporting Information), indicating that the contribution of CTH is negligible in the hydrogenation of LA.

We also investigated the effect of LHSV on the conversion of LA and the yield of GVL. As shown in Fig. 5c, with the increase of LHSV, the downtrend of LA conversion and GVL yield for Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst is distinctly slower than that of Cu/SBA-15. At a high LHSV of 5 h−1, the sample of Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 still displays a satisfying LA hydrogenation activity, giving a LA conversion of 95 % with the GVL yield as high as 74 %. In such a case, however, the GVL yield decreases to just 7 % with a LA conversion of 72 % for Cu/SBA-15 catalyst. Integrating the hydrogenation performance in Fig. 5 and characterization results above, we consider that highly dispersed ultrafine Cu clusters nanoconfined by g-C3N4 within SBA-15 provide sufficient active sites readily accessible to LA and beneficial to H2 dissociation, leading to the efficient hydrogenation of carbon-oxygen bonds. Furthermore, the Lewis base created by the N sites in g-C3N4 may promote the adsorption of acidic LA and consequently increase the LA concentration around the Cu clusters, which accelerate the following hydrogenation reaction [52,63]. The g-C3N4 can also confine the Cu clusters, which inhibits the agglomeration of Cu clusters during the catalytic process. As a result, the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst can achieve a high GVL yield at mild conditions.

For comparison, the hydrogenation activities of NC@SBA-15 and Cu/C@SBA-15 control samples were also investigated. As shown in Fig. 6 a and Fig. S13 (Supporting Information), bare NC@SBA-15 (without Cu) catalyst displays negligible activity of LA hydrogenation to GVL (0.5 %), verifying that metallic Cu clusters are the active centers for the hydrogenation reactions. Moreover, the Cu/C@SBA-15 catalyst exhibits a poor LA hydrogenation activity, with a GVL yield of only 41 %, which is mainly ascribed to a larger size and less uniform dispersion of Cu particles resulting from the absence of N sites in the sample. When the commercial Ru/AC catalyst (5 wt.% of Ru loaded on activated carbon) is applied, a GVL yield as high as 95 % can be obtained for LA hydrogenation. Surprisingly, the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 sample exhibits a comparable catalytic activity (92 % GVL yield) with that of Ru/AC catalyst under the same conditions. Furthermore, in a 100-h successive hydrogenation reaction process, the yield of GVL remains basically unchanged with LA fully converted (Fig. 6b), indicating that the Cu/NC@SBA-15−1.0 catalyst is robust and durable for GVL production. All these promising results imply that the catalysts illustrated in this work have a great potential for large-scale application in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL.

Theoretical calculations are useful in validating the proposed mechanism of LA to GVL and the effect of Cu nanoparticle size on the effectiveness of the catalyst. A 201-atom truncated octahedral, FCC Cu nanoparticle was selected to be a model for a “small” nanoparticle (see supporting information for a justification of this choice) and the (111) and (100) surface vacuum-cells were chosen to model the facets of a very “big” nanoparticle. Hydrogen was adsorbed on the exposed surfaces of all systems with a packing density of a quarter monolayer, in hollow sites on the (111) facets and bridge sites on the (100) facets.

Transition state (TS) search was performed using the Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method on a (111) and (100) facet of the 201-atom copper nanoparticle and on (111) and (100) copper surfaces [47]. We validated the assumption that the reaction occurs along the ML to 2-hydroxy methyl valerate (HMV) pathway, by comparing with the LA to 4-hydroxypentanoic acid (HPA) pathway, which we found to have a higher barrier to reaction (Fig. S14a, Supporting Information). We also assumed that atomic hydrogen is readily available, adsorbed near the reaction sites. As shown in Fig. 7 , a clear difference was found in the reaction barrier calculations between the small and large nanoparticle systems, showing that indeed, there is a size preference in this reaction for smaller nanoparticles. The (111) facet of the small nanoparticle possesses the lowest reaction barrier of 1.12 eV in comparison with other systems. It was also found that there was a strong preference towards the reaction happening on the (111) facets rather than (100). Finally, the binding strength of GVL on these systems is < 0.5 eV (Table S4, Supporting Information), indicating that it can leave the catalyst easily after the reaction has completed. A more detailed reaction energy profile from LA to GVL along the ML to HMV pathway on (111) sites of the nanoparticle and surface is presented in Fig. S14b (Supporting Information). The TS structures in the conversion from ML to HMV of the systems we studied are presented in Fig. 8 .

The site on the (111) facet of the nanoparticle has unambiguously the lowest barrier to reaction of the sites we studied. The chemical environment may be dramatically altered by varying the number of neighbours of a reaction site. So, to assess the data in a more objective way, the barrier to reaction can be plotted versus the generalized coordination number (GCN) [64]. This removes any uncertainty about the classification of sites and quantifies their description. After plotting this volcano-like chart (Fig. S15, Supporting Information), it gives us a clear indication that sites with GCN of around 6.9 have an optimum amount of electron density to catalyze the ML to HMV reaction. With this in mind and in the spirit of previous work [65], we plotted spherical nanoparticles from 1 atom up to an approximate diameter of 20 nm, monitoring those clusters having a proportion of more than 10 % of surface atoms with a GCN within 0.2 of 6.92. This allows sites with GCN near 6.92, but not as low as 6.66 or as high as 7.5, where our DFT calculations have already shown sub-optimal performance.

Spherical nanoparticles were examined with the central atom on the origin and with this atom shifted from the origin by 0.5 and 1.0 Angstroms. It was found that clusters of 1–3 nm across consistently had the highest proportion of surface GCN within 0.2 of 6.92 (Fig. S16, Supporting Information), with the 201-atom truncated octahedral nanoparticle leading the pack of all clusters that were examined. This finding leads us to two important conclusions. Firstly: smaller copper nanoparticles in the size range of the experimental clusters supported on g-C3N4 in SBA-15 are indeed predicted to have many more sites with a low barrier to reaction than larger nanoparticles. Secondly: more copper atoms are exposed on active sites, in the case of smaller clusters. This increased surface area probably enhances the activity of the smaller clusters, particularly as in this experiment, where the mass of copper is controlled.

The role of the g-C3N4 support was subsequently studied using further DFT calculations. Its form was assumed to be graphitic on the basis of stoichiometry. Upon testing a fragment of g-C3N4 binding to the (111) facet of the 201-atom truncated octahedral nanoparticle, the 2-coordinated nitrogen atoms were strongly attracted to the edge and vertex atoms of the copper nanoparticle. The reaction of ML to HMV on the most active site from the non-supported nanoparticle (GCN of 6.92), was repeated on an identical but g-C3N4 supported nanoparticle.

It is well known that metal atoms can shield chemical perturbations such as those introduced by a support within 2 or 3 atoms of distance. Those sites with GCN of 6.92 in the upper hemisphere of the nanoparticles, and the upper parts of the facets in the lower hemisphere, with respect to the support, retain the same activity as the non-supported case. It is also still true that the nanoparticles are small, so still have relatively large surface area and proportions of highly active sites.

A higher reaction barrier was found in the closest (111) site to the support (Fig. S17, Supporting Information). By investigating the Bader charges of the copper atoms (Fig. S18, Supporting Information), with and without g-C3N4, it was found that the reaction site has almost identical charge, whereas the atoms in contact with the g-C3N4 have significantly reduced charge [66]. The adsorbed, reacting hydrogen that is further away from the g-C3N4 maintains a similar binding strength of -0.46 eV, compared with -0.39 eV for its equivalent on the non-supported nanoparticle. The hydrogen that is closer to the g-C3N4, however, has a much stronger binding strength compared to its equivalent without g-C3N4. This explains the difference in reaction energy between the two cases and makes the case that the sites on which the hydrogen atoms are adsorbed equally important to the barrier height as the site on which the molecule is adsorbed (see Fig. S19, Supporting Information for hydrogen binding positions). However, the ML and HMV molecules are sufficiently large that only one reaction can fit on each facet, such that reducing the number of reaction sites available per facet will not negatively affect the activity of the nanoparticle.

In conclusion, Cu/NC@SBA-15 composite catalysts were readily constructed by one-step pyrolysis and in-situ reduction of SBA-15 molecular sieve impregnated with the mixture of urea and Cu(NO3)2. By benefiting from the coordinating and stabilizing effects of g-C3N4, tiny Cu clusters were evenly dispersed within SBA-15. The as-synthesized catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activities of LA hydrogenation to GVL in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. A GVL yield as high as 92 % was achieved at 140 °C with the optimized Cu/NC@SBA-15 catalyst, which is much higher than that of Cu/SBA-15 (37 %) and comparable with that of a commercial 5 wt.% Ru/AC (95 %). The proposed reaction mechanism and hydrogenation activity were validated with transition state DFT calculations and descriptor-based analysis. Copper clusters with sizes of less than 4 nm and a reaction barrier as low as 1.12 eV were found to be optimal for the reaction, in agreement with the experimental findings. This work provides promising candidates for the efficient production of high-value-added GVL through LA hydrogenation.
